factoid: Pelagéya Danílovna looked at strange but amusing capers cut by dancers.
The dancers had decided that being disguised, no one would recognize them.
The dancers were not shy.
Pelagéya Danílovna hid her face in her handkerchief.
Pelagéya Danílovna's whole stout body shook with irrepressible, kindly, elderly laughter.
Pelagéya Danílovna said "My little Sásha! Look at Sásha!".
Pelagéya Danílovna made the serfs and gentry join in one large circle.
A ring was fetched for the circle game.
A string was fetched for the circle game.
A silver ruble was fetched for the circle game.
The serfs and gentry played games together.
After an hour, all costumes were crumpled and disordered.
The corked eyebrows and mustaches were smeared over the perspiring, flushed, and merry faces.
Pelagéya Danílovna recognized the mummers.
Pelagéya Danílovna admired the mummers' cleverly contrived costumes.
Pelagéya Danílovna admired how the mummers' costumes suited the young ladies.
Pelagéya Danílovna thanked the mummers for entertaining her so well.
The visitors were invited to supper in the drawing room.
The serfs were served something in the ballroom.
The old maid who lived with the Melyukóvs said "Now to tell one's fortune in the empty bathhouse is frightening!" during supper.
The eldest Melyukóv girl asked "Why?".
The old maid who lived with the Melyukóvs said "You wouldn't go, it takes courage."
Sónya said "I'll go."
The second Melyukóv girl said "Tell what happened to the young lady!"
The old maid who lived with the Melyukóvs told a story about a young lady who once went out, took a cock, laid the table for two properly, and sat down.
The young lady suddenly heard someone coming.
A sleigh drove up with harness bells.
The young lady heard the man coming.
The man came in in the shape of a man, like an officer, and sat down at the table with the young lady.
Natásha screamed "Ah! ah!" and rolled her eyes with horror.
Natásha asked "Yes? And how did he speak?"
The old maid who lived with the Melyukóvs replied "Yes, like a man."
The old maid who lived with the Melyukóvs said the man began persuading the young lady.
The old maid who lived with the Melyukóvs said the young lady should have kept the man talking till cockcrow.
The young lady got frightened and hid her face in her hands.
The old maid who lived with the Melyukóvs said the man caught her up.
The old maid who lived with the Melyukóvs said it was lucky the maids ran in just then.
Pelagéya Danílovna asked "Now, why frighten them?"
Pelagéya Danílovna's daughter said "Mamma, you used to try your fate yourself."
Sónya inquired "And how does one do it in a barn?"
The old maid who lived with the Melyukóvs replied "Well, say you went to the barn now, and listened."
The old maid who lived with the Melyukóvs said it depends on what you hear; hammering and knocking is bad.
The old maid who lived with the Melyukóvs said a sound of shifting grain is good.
The old maid who lived with the Melyukóvs said one sometimes hears that too.
Pelagéya Danílovna's daughter asked "Mamma, tell us what happened to you in the barn."
Pelagéya Danílovna smiled.
Pelagéya Danílovna said "Oh, I've forgotten."
Pelagéya Danílovna's daughter asked "But none of you would go?"
Pelagéya Danílovna's daughter said "Yes, I will; Pelagéya Danílovna, let me! I'll go."
Sónya asked "Louisa Ivánovna, may I?"
Nicholas did not leave Sónya's side.
Nicholas gazed at Sónya with new eyes.
Nicholas thought that it was only today, thanks to that burnt-cork mustache, that he had fully learned to know Sónya.
That evening, Sónya was brighter, more animated, and prettier than Nicholas had ever seen her before.
Nicholas thought "So that's what she is like; what a fool I have been!"
Nicholas gazed at Sónya's sparkling eyes.
Under Nicholas's mustache a happy rapturous smile dimpled his cheeks.
Nicholas had never seen that smile before.
Sónya said "I'm not afraid of anything."
Sónya said "May I go at once?"
Sónya got up.
They told Sónya where the barn was and how she should stand and listen.
They handed Sónya a fur cloak.
Sónya threw the cloak over her head and shoulders.
Sónya glanced at Nicholas.
Nicholas thought "What a darling that girl is!"
Sónya went out into the passage to go to the barn.
Nicholas went hastily to the front porch, saying he felt too hot.
The crowd of people made the house stuffy.
